items.item_text_raw: 1. 4:30 p.m. - Call Meeting to Order at the District Board Room, 4750 San Felipe Road, San Jose, CA 95135.

items.item_details:
The Board of Trustees offers an opportunity for the public to address the Board in four sections of the agenda: on matters of concern about Closed Session items; on matters not appearing on the agenda; on action items contained in the Consent Agenda; and prior to voting on any item contained in the Action Agenda. Each speaker is encouraged to submit a comment card to the Board clerk in order to be recognized to speak.
	Per Board Policy, three minutes may be allotted to each speaker with a maximum of 30 minutes per subject. No action or discussion shall be undertaken on any public comments except that members of the Board or its staff may briefly respond to or ask a question for clarification regarding statements made or questions posed by persons addressing the Board under this agenda item.
	For information and disability access to materials, call 408-270-6402. Meetings are held in a location accessible to the disabled.

items.item_details:
1. Evergreen Valley College Adjunct Faculty
Per the collective bargaining agreement between the AFT 6157 and San Jose/Evergreen Community College District Article 9.19 submission and recommendation: Adjunct faculty members shall be responsible and accountable for all District assigned services during the college semester for which they are employed. Assignments are limited to a maximum of 67% of the full load.
				 
Article 9.19 ASSIGNMENT LENGTH AND MAXIMUM LOADING - Adjunct faculty members shall be responsible and accountable for all District assigned service during the college semester for which they are employed. Assignments are limited to a maximum of 67% of a full load.
Therefore, the attached information is in compliance with Article 9.19 of the Faculty Association AFT 6157 Collective Bargaining Agreement with San Jose/Evergreen Community College District.
				 
A-EVC Adjunct Faculty October 14, 2014

items.item_details: The District employs non-bargaining unit employees in various categories to support programs and services.  These categories are: short-term assignments with limitations as defined in the CSEA/District collective bargaining agreement; substitutes to fill positions for employees on leave of absence or in vacant positions; professional experts with specialized knowledge or expertise not generally required of, or found within, the employee classifications established by the Governing Board; and athletic support staff for athletic activities.

items.item_details:
Education Code 81655 stipulates that no contract is an enforceable obligation of the District until it has been approved by the Board of Trustees. Board Policy 6100 establishes the authority of certain administrators to approve contracts under the bid limit prior to formal Board approval. All contracts, purchase orders and contract revisions exceeding the current bid limit of $84,100 shall have prior Board approval as a separate board item.
This consent item presents for Board approval: all purchase orders for this period, which includes purchase orders for administratively approved contracts exceeding $1,000, as well as additional contracts, although not executed by way of purchase order, are deemed appropriate to be added by the Purchasing Department.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees ratify the contracts, purchase orders and contract revisions for the period of August 10, 2014 through September 9, 2014 as noted in the attached documents.

items.item_details:
The U.S. Department of Education under the Title V Hispanic-Serving Institutions Program has awarded SJCC a five-year grant totaling $2,478,135.
	 
	 
	 
SJCC’s Title V project responds systemically to an increased need in recent years for support services to low-income and Hispanic students that will help them to be successful in college. This Title V grant project, Caminos will overcome weaknesses identified through a comprehensive analysis process and will put in place student-centered support services based on “high impact practices” and on our institutional experience creating academic opportunities for our highly diverse student population. 
Caminos has a single activity designed to help eliminate many problems identified at SJCC, including a need for additional support services that will assist students in being successful in college from entry through graduation or transfer. The results of these efforts are reflected in our four major objectives:
	 
Objective 1: The completion rate (degree, certificate or transfer-related outcomes) for students in the Caminos Project will exceed the current rate of 34% for underprepared students to 50% in year 4 and 70% in year 5 in our effort to reach the current completion rate of 70.6 % for college prepared students;
	 
Objective 2: 79%of the students in the Caminos Project will persist (enroll in 3 consecutive semesters) and complete 15 units (current rate of 65%);       
	 
Objective 3: 70% of students in the Caminos Project will complete 30 units within 2 years of their initial enrollment; and, 
	 
Objective 4: 70% of students in the Caminos Project who complete more than 18 units of Career Technical Education Program within 3 years of their initial enrollment, compared to baseline of 54%.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees accept Year 1 grant funds awarded to San Jose City College for the grant period effective October 1, 2014 through September 30, 2015 in the amount of $505,847 from the U.S. Department of Education, Title V Hispanic-Serving Institutions Program.
items.item_text: Acceptance of Grant Funds – San Jose City College
items.item_text_raw: 11. Acceptance of Grant Funds – San Jose City College

items.item_details:
Since 2005, Workforce Institute has contracted with the City of San Jose to provide WIA Youth intensive services and is being funded to continue those services for the 2014-15 program year. Services include outreach, eligibility determination, assessment, job development/placement services, and follow-up services for youth ages 18-21, who are low income with at least one barrier to obtaining employment. Services will be delivered at the work2future Youth Training Center in San Jose and the South County One-Stop in Gilroy.
	 
Contract funding for the 2014-2015 Program Year is $425,000.00
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the 2014–2015 WIA Youth Contract in the amount of $425,000.00.
items.item_text: Workforce Institute – 2014-2015 WIA work2future Youth Contract
items.item_text_raw: 12. Workforce Institute – 2014-2015 WIA work2future Youth Contract

items.item_details:
BACKGROUND: Since 2000, the Workforce Institute has contracted with the City of San Jose (work2future) to provide a wide variety of job readiness workshops to Santa Clara job seekers at multiple locations. Additionally, the Workforce Institute has provided online training to equip job seekers with the skills (high level programming, project management, accounting, entrepreneurship, etc.) they need to market themselves in this and future competitive job markets.
	 
Beginning 2012, work2future began awarding NTE contract pools to its service providers.  The overall contract dollars are allocated to the various providers of instructor led workshops and online training as needed.  Actual revenue earned through the WIA Overall Workshop Pool Contract is predicated on clients choosing Workforce Institute courses from a menu of workshops offered via the multiple providers.
	 
2012-2013 CONTRACT:  On September 11, 2012, the Board of Trustees approved Workforce Institute’s $600,000 NTE Pool Contract awarded by work2future – City of San Jose for FY 2012 – 2013.
	 
FIRST AMENDMENT:   On July 9, 2013, the Board of Trustees approved a $205,267.00 First Amendment to the 2012-2013 WIA Overall Occupational Skills Training Pool Contract. 
	 
SECOND AMENDMENT: On September 10, 2013, the Board of Trustees approved a $2,091,767 Second Amendment to the 2012-2013 WIA Overall Occupational Skills Training Pool Contract. 
	 
THIRD AMENDMENT:  In this Third Amendment to the 2012-2013 WIA Overall Occupational Skills Training Pool Contract the City of San Jose is amending the above referenced contract.  The amendments include the overall occupational skills training pool in the amount of $1,574,858 for fiscal year 2014-2015; modifies the term to 7/1/2012 through 6/30/2015; reflects a change in name from ”One-Stop Center” to “America's Job Center of California (AJCC)” and a change in locations for the AJCCs. 
	 
Workforce Institute anticipates realizing $312,000 in 2014-2015 from this Overall Occupational Skills Training Pool Contract.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the Third Amendment to the WIA Overall Occupational Skills Training Pool Contract
items.item_text: Workforce Institute – Third Amendment to WIA Overall Occupational Skills Training Pool Contract
items.item_text_raw: 13. Workforce Institute – Third Amendment to WIA Overall Occupational Skills Training Pool Contract

items.item_details:
This new College Admission Application will be hosted by the CCCTC and replace the current CCCApply application that is hosted by XAP. This will be provided at no cost and will result in a cost savings to the colleges. It will also enable the colleges to participate in other statewide applications such as the upcoming Online Education Initiative.  
	 
	MOU Synopsis: 
	 
	The purpose of the MOU is to define the roles and responsibilities of the parties as it relates to the California Community Colleges online electronic admission application:
	 
	CCCTC will operate, maintain, update and provide user support for participating institution in their use of the OpenCCCApply System online common admission applications. 
	 
	Participating Institution will accept and process applications as official applications, establish and maintain links from their website to System, review and update information on the System semi-annually, and support CCC Federated Identity Initiative (OpenCCC Federation) and System-wide  implementation of a common student identifier (CCCID).
	 
	Institution will coordinate with Terry McCune and staff at the CCC Technology Center.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve this no-cost MOU with CCCTC through June 30, 2015 for SJCC and EVC to migrate to the new CCCApply Admission Application.
items.item_text: No-Cost Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) with California Community Colleges Technology Center (CCCTC) for OpenCCCApply Institution Participation through June 30, 2015
items.item_text_raw: 14. No-Cost Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) with California Community Colleges Technology Center (CCCTC) for OpenCCCApply Institution Participation through June 30, 2015

items.item_details:
On August 1, 2014 Bid Proposal #14-0825 - Educational Master Plan (EMP) and Related Facilities Master Plan (FMP) was advertised. The RFP went out to known EMP and FMP vendors as well as other public venues. The proposals were assessed and ranked by an evaluation committee comprised of a Purchasing Agent, District Office personnel and personnel from EVC, SJCC, and the Workforce Institute. Vendors had the option to bid in one of three ways:  EMP only, FMP only, or both EMP and FMP.  Those who bid for both the EMP and the FMP were given the option to partner with another firm.  Of the five vendors who bid for the Educational Master Plan, three were invited to present to the committee.  Of the six vendors who bid for the Facilities Master Plan, three were invited to present to the committee.  Attached is the list of vendors who participated in the RFP, the criteria by which each of the vendors were evaluated, and the contract that is being recommended to the Board.
	 
This board item will deal with the Educational Master Plan only, with the related Facilities Master Plan to come at a later board meeting.  The recommendation is that the Board award the contract to Cambridge West Partnership, LLC. to deliver one educational master plan each for San Jose City College and Evergreen Valley College.  The contract duration is from October 14, 2014 through December 30, 2015.  The price of this contract is $270,000.  Cambridge West Partnership, LLC is a qualified minority and women owned business.
	 
Attached is the executed contract, the list of vendors who responded to the RFP, and the RFP with the evaluation criteria.
	 
	 
	.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees award the Contract for Request for Proposal 14-0825, Educational Master Plan (EMP) to Cambridge West LLC
items.item_text: Award of Contract for Request for Proposal 14-0825, Educational Master Plan
items.item_text_raw: 15. Award of Contract for Request for Proposal 14-0825, Educational Master Plan

items.item_details:
Evergreen Valley College (EVC) accepted transfer of two TRIO programs from National Hispanic University and agreed to assume and maintain administrative responsibility over the grant applications approved by the U.S. Department of Education for Upward Bound Program and the Talent Search Program.  President Henry Yong received notification from the U.S. Department of Education stating that as of September 1, 2014 both the Upward Bound and Talent Search grants had officially been transferred to EVC. 
	 
Board approval is requested to accept transfer of TRIO programs and receipt of grant funds.  
Upward Bound annual grant allocation $230,850.65, entering its second program cycle with three years remaining on the grant (2012-2017).
Talent Search annual grant allocation $387, 800.44, entering its third program cycle with two years remaining on the grant (2011-2016)
Grant Transfer Notification forms are attached for review and approval.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve transfer of two TRIO Programs from National Hispanic University to Evergreen Valley College.

items.item_details:
The contract for Campus Site Improvements – Phase 1 Project #31116-02 at San Jose City College, includes necessary pruning and the removal of existing trees that were sick, dead, or otherwise affecting campus health and safety. 
	 
On July 28, 2014, the Board of Trustees approved the Agreement, for Bay Area Tree Specialists to perform the work.  On July 8, 2014, construction activity began and on September 12, 2014 major construction activity was completed.  As of September 12, 2014 all construction work has been approved by the Architect of Record, all closeout documents have been received, and all Change Orders have been approved. 
	 
Once approved, this Notice of Completion (NOC) will be filed with the County of Santa Clara, Office of the Recorder.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the Notice of Completion (NOC) of the contract by Bay Area Tree Specialists, for the Campus Site Improvement – Phase 1 project, #31116-02 at San Jose City College.

items.item_details:
On October 8, 2013 the Board of Trustees approved a contract to XL Construction in the amount of $6,100,000 to provide construction services or products for The New District Office Building Project #39301 at the SJECCD. 
	 
Construction contracts commonly experience unforeseen conditions, or District request design changes that require an adjustment to the contract, scope, price and/or duration in the form of a Change Order. Change Order No.004 is for differing site conditions, deductive credit back, and District requested changes.
	 
XL Construction submitted written pricing proposals for these changes (details in the attachment) that include the applicable increase or decrease in materials, equipment, labor, time extensions and overhead and profit.  The proposals have been reviewed to ensure the pricing reflects compliance with contract terms.
	 
Original Contract Amount                     $6,100,000
Previously Approved Changes             $   845,141
Change Order No.004                          $   100,815
	 
Revised Contract Amount                     $7,045,956
	 
The net change to XL Construction's contract as a result of all changes issued is $945,956 which equates to 15.5% of the original contract. This change will be funded from project contingency established in the project budget in expectation of this type of change.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve Change Order No. 004 in the amount of $100,815 to XL Construction, for the New District Office Building Project #39301 at SJECCD.
items.item_text: Measure G-2010 Bond Program: San Jose Evergreen Community College District (SJECCD) - New District Office Building, Project #39301 – XL Construction – Change Order No. 004
items.item_text_raw: 3. Measure G-2010 Bond Program: San Jose Evergreen Community College District (SJECCD) - New District Office Building, Project #39301 – XL Construction – Change Order No. 004

items.item_details:
The scope of this Contract is for audiovisual systems to be installed by an audiovisual systems contractor. The project entails furnishing and installation of audio and visual components in various conference, boardroom, multi-purpose, offices, and IT training rooms.  
	 
The project was posted on the District’s purchasing website and advertised in local papers on August 28, 2014 and September 4, 2014.  It was also published at local builders’ exchanges and plan rooms.  In addition, invitations to bid were sent to over 20 contractors including small, minority and woman-owned firms.  On September 25, 2014 base bids were received as follows:
	 
            Integrated Communication Systems      $299,656.00
            PCD Audio Visual System Integration   $383,398.00
            Spinitar                                                   $399,600.00
           
	 
Integrated Communication Systems from San Jose, California was determined to be the lowest responsive and responsible bidder in the amount of $388,620.00.  Alternate bid prices were received for nine (9) items totaling $88,964.00, which are also recommended for award along with the base bid.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the Award of a Contract in the amount of $388,620.00 to Integrated Communication Systems, for the New District Office Building Project #39301 – Audio Visual System at SJECCD.
items.item_text: Measure G –2010 Bond Program: San Jose Evergreen Community College District (SJECCD): New District Office Building Project #39301 – Audio Visual System- Integrated Communications System Agreement
items.item_text_raw: 4. Measure G –2010 Bond Program: San Jose Evergreen Community College District (SJECCD): New District Office Building Project #39301 – Audio Visual System- Integrated Communications System Agreement

items.item_details:
The scope of the Contract includes the installation of Ethernet enabled Axis Video Surveillance Cameras, Door Controllers, Panic Switches, Card Readers, Wireless Lock Interfaces, Recessed Door Contacts, and Request-to-Exit Detectors at strategic locations within the New District Office to meet District security standards.
 
The project was posted on the District’s purchasing website and advertised in local papers on August 28, 2014 and September 5, 2014.  It was published at local builders’ exchanges and plan rooms.  In addition, invitations to bid were sent to over 20 contractors including small, minority and woman-owned firms.  On September 25, 2014, bids were received on that design.  Base bids were received as follows:
 
            Walsh Electronics Integration  $111,282.00
            Electronic Innovations             $130,374.31
            VAS Security Systems, Inc.     $219,833.44
           
 
Walsh Electronics Integration from Clayton, California was determined to be the lowest responsive and responsible bidder in the amount of $125,613.00.  Alternate bid prices were received for one (1) item totaling $14,331.00, which is also recommended for award along with the base bid.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the award of an Agreement in the amount of $125,613.00 to Walsh Electronics Systems Technology, for the District Office Security System #39301 at San Jose City Evergreen Community College District.

items.item_details:
On April 8, 2014 the Board of Trustees approved a contract to Electronic Innovations in the amount of $70,476.00 to provide construction services and products for Physical Security Project #31311 at San Jose City College.
 
Construction contracts commonly experience unforeseen conditions or District required design changes that require an adjustment to the contract, scope, price and/or duration in the form of a Change Order.  Change Order No. 002 is for the installation of extra conduit. 
 
Electronic Innovations submitted written pricing proposals for these changes (details in the agenda attachment) that includes the applicable increase or decrease in materials, equipment, labor, time extensions and overhead and profit. The proposals have been reviewed to ensure the pricing reflects compliance with contract terms.
 
Original Contract Amount                    $ 70,476.00
Previously Approved Changes           -$   5,000.00
Change Order No. 002                        $   2,700.00 
Revised Contract Amount                   $ 68,176.00
 
The net change to Electronic Innovations contract as a result of all changes issued is -$2,300.00 which equates to -3.3% of the original contract.  This change will be funded from project contingency established in the project budget in expectations of this type of change.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve Change Order No. 002 in the amount of $2,700.00 to Electronic Innovations, for the Physical Security Project #31311 at San Jose City College.
items.item_text: Measure G –2010 Bond Program: San Jose City College Physical Security Project #31311– Electronic Innovations Change Order No. 002
items.item_text_raw: 6. Measure G –2010 Bond Program: San Jose City College Physical Security Project #31311– Electronic Innovations Change Order No. 002

items.item_details:
The contract for the Parking Lot and Street Maintenance Project #32313 at Evergreen Valley College was necessary to improve Student Parking Lots and entry road Paseo De Arboles. 
	 
On December 10, 2013 the Board approved the Agreement for Galeb Paving, Inc. to perform construction services for the first phase of parking lots & street maintenance projects at Evergreen Valley College.  On January 27, 2014, construction activity began and on August 31, 2014, major construction activity was completed.  As of August 31, 2014 all construction work has been approved by the Architect of Record, all closeout documents have been received, Change Orders have been approved and all contracts have been closed.  
	 
Once approved, this Notice of Completion will be filed with the County of Santa Clara, Office of Recorder.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the Notice of Completion (NOC) of Galeb Paving, Inc. for the Parking Lot and Street Maintenance Project #32313 at Evergreen Valley College.
items.item_text: Measure G-2010 Bond Program: Evergreen Valley College Parking Lot and Street Maintenance Project #32313 – Galeb Paving, Inc. Notice of Completion (NOC)
items.item_text_raw: 7. Measure G-2010 Bond Program: Evergreen Valley College Parking Lot and Street Maintenance Project #32313 – Galeb Paving, Inc. Notice of Completion (NOC)

﻿﻿On July 8, 2014, the Board approved a contract to H.Y. Floor & Gameline Painting in the amount of $35,356 to provide construction services for the Gym Floor Refinishing Project #32307-01 at Evergreen Valley College. 
On July 8, 2014, the Board approved a contract to H.Y. Floor & Gameline Painting in the amount of $35,356 to provide construction services for the Gym Floor Refinishing Project #32307-01 at Evergreen Valley College. 
	 
Construction contracts commonly experience unforeseen conditions or District requested design changes that require an adjustment to the contract scope, price and/or duration in the form of a Change Order.  Deductive Change Order No. 001 includes a credit for the remaining un-used Allowance #1 for unforeseen conditions.    
	 
H.Y. Floor & Gameline Painting submitted written pricing proposals for changes that include the applicable increase or decrease in materials, equipment, labor, time extensions, and overhead and profit.  The proposals have been reviewed to ensure the pricing reflects compliance with contract terms.

Previously Approved Changes             $         0

The net change to the H.Y. Floor & Gameline Painting contract as a result of all changes issued is ($4,700), which equates to (13.29%) of the original contract.  The funds generated by this change will be returned to project contingency.

On June 10, 2014, the Board of Trustees approved a contract to JKL Construction Services, Inc. in the amount of $306,224 to provide construction services for the Mechanical Plumbing and Electrical Upgrade Package 2 Project #32307-06 at Evergreen Valley College.   
	 
Construction contracts commonly experience unforeseen conditions or District requested design changes that require an adjustment to the contract scope, price and/or duration in the form of a Change Order.  Change Order No. 002 includes costs for added premium time on a Saturday to install the Manual Transfer Switch at the Gullo building, and a credit for the un-used balance of Allowance #2.   
	 
JKL Construction Services, Inc. submitted written pricing proposals for changes detailed in the Agenda attachment that include the applicable increase or decrease in materials, equipment, labor, time extensions, and overhead and profit.  The proposals have been reviewed to ensure the pricing reflects compliance with contract terms.
	 
Original Contract Amount                    $306,224
Previously Approved Changes            $  16,316
Change Order No. 002                        $    3,983
	 
Revised Contract Amount                   $326,523
	 
The net change to JKL Construction Services, Inc. contract as a result of all changes issued is $20,299, which equates to 6.63% of the original contract.  This change will be funded from project contingency established in the project budget in expectation of this type of change.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve Change Order No. 002 in the amount of $3,983 to JKL Construction Services, Inc. for the Mechanical Plumbing and Electrical Upgrade Package 2 Project #32307-06 at Evergreen Valley College.

items.item_details:
On August 26, 2014, the Board of Trustees approved an Agreement to Blach Construction Company in the amount of $41,639,729 to provide construction services for the South Campus Development Project #32107 at Evergreen Valley College.
Construction contracts commonly experience unforeseen conditions or District request design changes that require an adjustment to the contract scope, price and/or duration in the form of a Change Order.   Change Order No. 001 includes credits for a general liability insurance allowance that is now not required and for a bid package calculation error in the Guaranteed Maximum Price (GMP) for signage scope, and added costs for a student pathway around the north end of the construction site required by the College and for items required to support the Inspector of Record (IOR).
	 
Blach Construction Company submitted written pricing proposals for these changes detailed in the Agenda attachment that include the applicable increase or decrease in materials, equipment, labor, time extensions, and overhead and profit. The proposals have been reviewed to ensure the pricing reflects compliance with contract terms.  
	 
Original Contract Amount                             $41,639,729
Previously Approved Changes                     $                0
Deductive Change Order No. 001               ($    400,834)
	 
	 
Revised Contract Amount                             $41,238,895
	 
The net change to Blach Construction Company’s contract as a result of all changes issued is ($400,834), which equates to (0.96%) of the original contract.  The funds from this change will be returned to the overall project budget.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve Deductive Change Order No. 001 in the amount of ($400,834) to Blach Construction Company for the South Campus Development Project #32107 at Evergreen Valley College.

items.item_details: HMC Architects, with district and college representatives and Gilbane, has been working through the process to create District Standards and Campus Design Guidelines.  These standards have been drafted, reviewed and revised as part of the review process.  To complete the shared-governance review, additional meetings are necessary to present and receive comments on the Standards as they have been developed.  These meetings require extension of the contract time for HMC Architects, from August 29, 2014 to December 31, 2014.  It is anticipated that this will be sufficient time to finalize the Standards and Guidelines for presentation to the Board of Trustees.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve Revision No. 003 to HMC Architects to extend the contract time (no-cost) of the SJECCD District Standards & Campus Design Guidelines Agreement from August 29, 2014 to December 31, 2014 to accommodate the necessary approval processes.

items.item_details:
On August 26, 2014, the Board of Trustees approved a Master Agreement with Dasher Technologies for Information Technology Systems and Infrastructure Design Services.  This Project Amendment Authorization request (PAA #EVC001) is for Dasher Technology to provide discovery services for the Evergreen Valley College campus, in support of the eventual relocation of the Main Distribution frame (MDF) from the Roble building to the Student Services Center.  Discovery services include:
 
Inventory of existing network equipment in Roble building, document new systems to be installed in the Student Services Center and room sizing/layout for the MDF in the Student Services Center.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve PAA # EVC 001 with Dasher Technologies in the amount of $11,520 to provide discovery services for the relocation of the Main Distribution Frame (MDF) from Roble building to the Student Services Center.

Total cost with tax is $238,045.

items.item_details: It is recommended that the Board of Trustees of the San José-Evergreen Community College District approves a resolution in support of Filipino American History Month, October, 2014, and the many students, faculty, staff and administrators of Filipino American heritage that have made numerous contributions of great value to our Colleges/District. The District also expresses appreciation to the many faculty and staff members, who have created educational events in October that pay tribute to Filipino American History Month 2014.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve Resolution No. 101414-2 in support of Filipino American History Month

items.item_details:
Background
	 
On February 12, 2013, the San José-Evergreen Community College District Board of Trustees scheduled a “Study Session” and embarked on a transformational journey.   The goal of that session was described as follows: 
	 
“…to build a sense of team and the importance of speaking with "one voice." The session will build a clear understanding of the role of individual board members and the role and authority of the board as a whole, using this understanding as a frame of reference to review critical components of effective trusteeship, evaluate current practices and identify areas in need of change. Some of the specific topics for review and discussion will include:
	 
•   Board Vision/Mission/Goals
•   Effective Governance Processes: The Carver Governance Model
•   Current Board Structure: Committees and Task Forces
•   Board Self Evaluation and Workplan Development
•   Board Skills Development Program
•   Board Master Calendar
	 
More than one year later and after thirteen more scheduled discussions, including weekend study sessions; the board of trustees finally approved a document on May 13, 2014, under the heading “San José-Evergreen Community College District, Board of Trustees Ends Policies and Governance Principles.”
	 
	 
http://www.sjeccd.edu/Chancellor/Documents/SJECCD%20Board_Ends%20Policies_Governance%20Principles%205%2013%2014.pdf
	 
	 
	 
Implementation Step 1 : Lessons Learned from Ends to Means
	 
The work of the Board has been described as transformational, but there has also been significant change in the work of staff.  Having clarity about the Board’s policy directives require the clear identification of strategies that staff must utilize and deploy to ensure implementation.  Furthermore, these strategies (i.e. means) must also be quantifiable in order to demonstrate accountability and progress. There are several principles or guideposts that emerged from board discussions on the matter of governance and policy development that we as staff have used to guide the development of our workplans.  Listed below are a few of these key precepts:
A Board that does not prescribe ends has no target
Prescribing ends is an absolute priority but prescribing means is not
Describing the target to be hit and what to avoid is governance; doing it is management.
The Board controls operational means by describing the parameters of what is unacceptable. These parameters include compliance with the following:
Law
Ethics
Fair Treatment of Employees
Prudence/Diligence
Staff work is both accountable and measurable
If we have staff that is afraid of failure, then we have staff that is mediocre
	 
Implementation Step 2 - Workplan Development
	 
This report presents the work undertaken by Executive Staff designed to identify the “means strategies” that will enable the implementation of the “ends policies” as prescribed by the Board of Trustees. The Chancellor charged staff with the development of individual workplans and the identification of means strategies that would contribute, advance and “move the needle” toward the implementation of the Board’s “global ends policies.”   This task, while time consuming, turned yielded a series of unintended but welcomed organizational outcomes in several areas including:
Board Policy Alignment – Development of a crossover between Board’s Ends Policies and Board’s Strategic Priorities (see attachment A)
Strategic Planning Alignment - Alignment of multiple strategic planning documents (i.e. Educational, Facilities, Technology, Human Resources, Budget and Research)
Interdependence - Development of side-by-side workplan comparisons demonstrating the crossover and support provided from one division/staff person to another.  In other words, we have been able to identify areas in which the work in one college, administrative unit or department clearly supports and, in some instances, clearly depends on the work of another.
Gaps and Duplications – Workplan development and comparisons have also helped to identify gaps and eliminate duplication of effort.
Resource Allocation -  Alignment, focus and direction has increased staff’s ability to determine the most effective and efficient ways in which to allocate resources (fiscal, human, facilities etc.)
Changing the "Script" – The consistent use of new terminology (i.e. ends, means) has resulted in the development of communications and work products that reflect and continuously re-enforce our focus and progress toward a single direction; namely, the implementation of the Board’s Global Ends Policies.
	 
The  Chancellor Workplan
	 
In reviewing the SJECCD Global Ends Statement Chancellor Workplan (See attachment B), the reader should take into account several considerations:
	 
Format/Organization - The Workplan begins with a staff response to the board's "Global End Statement" and its six subcategories (Career Development, Transfer, College Readiness, Institutional Excellence, Student Success and the College Experience).  The matrix then aligns each of these areas with the 2013-2017 Strategic Priorities previously established by the board. The matrix concludes with a proposed "metric" designed to measure the impact that each of these efforts will have in each designated area.
	 
Targeted Emphasis - As expected, the Presidents' workplans are the most comprehensive, impacting all areas of the enterprise. It is for this reason that the presidents' work is listed first.   Vice Chancellors and other Executive Staff follow; and their workplans clearly target the area of "Institutional Excellence," focusing greatly on the supportive work, infrastructure development and the attendant fiscal, human resources, reporting and legal structures that sustain the work of the colleges.
	 
Topics and Themes - It is gratifying to note that regardless of the area of focus nearly all of the strategies and metrics identified clearly focus on students and their success.
	 
Faculty and Staff Development - It is clear from the strategies identified that our District must increase its investment in the development of added and targeted expertise of faculty and staff.  As we undergo significant transformations in curriculum, technology, reporting process and expected outcomes and accountability; it is critical that we identify and provide the necessary training and upgrades to move in the right direction.
	 
Constructive Criticism - We are clearly still in a developmental process including a "culture change" regarding the way in which we view our work.  Some of our strategies still appear to be more like tasks than long range objectives, but this is to be expected given our need to ensure continuity of effort.
	 
Informed Decision Making – Ongoing analysis and reporting of data is expected to inform decisions to adjust, increase or rethink work at the individual and composite team level.
	 
Next Steps
	 
Development of the Board's 2015 Agenda- The Executive Workplan will form the basis for the Board's Agenda items for the 2015 Calendar Year.  The Board's Revised Governance Process has three basic components (1) the development of Global Statements,(2) the establishment of "Means Strategies/Workplan" to implement the Board's mandate and (3) the development of an annual agenda that ensures ongoing reporting on the attainment of each objective.  This last component is achieved through the establishment of a year long agenda for the Board.  It is expected that a proposed draft agenda will be brought to the Board of Trustees at its next meeting (10/28/14) to prepare for final adoption before the election of new board officers in December.
items.item_text: Board "Global Ends" Policies and Executive Staff "Means" Strategies: An Implementation Workplan
items.item_text_raw: 1. Board "Global Ends" Policies and Executive Staff "Means" Strategies: An Implementation Workplan

items.item_details:
The 2013-2014 State Budget appropriated $25 million to the California Community College Chancellorâs Office (CCCCO) to allocate funding for planning and implementation grants to eligible consortia for the purpose of developing regional plans for adult education. 
	 
Assembly Bill 86 (AB 86) outlines expectations for consortium development as well as planning and implementation requirements to establish the Adult Education Consortium Program. The intent of AB 86 is to create an integrated adult learner system that increases transition to post-secondary education and enhances employability based on individual student goals. 
                               
The South Bay Consortia for Adult Education (SBCAE) is the consortia formed to develop the south bay Regional Plan for Adult Education of which San Jose Evergreen Community College District is one of seven districts playing an active role.  
	 
This information item is intended to provide an update on AB 86 Objectives and Progress Reporting, SBCAEâs regional leadership, and the breadth of stakeholder involvement in the development of the regional plan for adult education.
items.item_text: AB86 - South Bay Consortium for Adult Education Progress Report
items.item_text_raw: 2. AB86 - South Bay Consortium for Adult Education Progress Report
